tuv.seg: There are two types of criminal offences:
Tá dhá chineál coir choiriúil ann;
• Summary offences, that is, offences that are tried by a judge sitting alone
• Cionta Achomaire, sé sin, cionta a thagann ós comhair Breithimh atá ina aonar
• Indictable offences, that is, offences that can be tried by a judge and jury
• Cionta indíotáilte , sé sin, cionta a thagann ós comhair Breithimh agus giuiré le chéile
Certain indictable offences may be tried summarily
Is féidir cionta indíotáilte áirithe a thriail go hachomair
If you are accused of a criminal offence, you may qualify for criminal legal aid, which provides free legal representation in criminal cases
Má tá cion coiriúil curtha i do leith b'fhéidir go bhfuil tú i dteideal cúnamh dlí choiriúil, rud a thugannionadaíocht dlí i gcásanna coiriúla saor in aisce duit
There are two types of trial:
Tá dhá chineál trialach ann:
• A summary trial - a trial conducted by a judge sitting alone
• Triail achomaire - triail ós comhair breithimh atá ina aonar
• Trial by jury - a trial conducted by a judge sitting with a jury
• Triail ghiúré - triail ós comhair breithimh agus giúré le chéile
Summary trials are heard in the District Court
Chloiseann siad trialacha achoimre sa Chúirt Dúiche

If you are charged with an indictable offence, the District Court Judge will send you forward to the Circuit Court or the Central Criminal Court (High Court) for trial by jury providing the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) consents to it

Má tá tú cúisithe i gcion indíotáilte, cuireann an Chúirt Dúiche Breitheamh tú ar aghaidh chuig an gCúirt Chuarda nó Phríomh-Chúirt Choiriúil (Ard-Chúirt) chun trialach le giúiré má aontaíonn an Stiúrthóir Ionchúiseamh Poiblí (DPP)
The court that will hear and decide on your case depends on the type of offence involved
Braitheann sé ar an gcinneál cion atá i gceist cén chúirt a éisteann an cás
Before the actual trial takes place, there are a number of issues that come up including the disclosure of evidence and the option of pleading guilty
Sula dtagann an cás chun trialach, tá roinnt nithe eile nach mór a bheith ullamh, ina measc seo tá fianaise a nochtadh agus an rogha maidir le pléadáil ciontach
After the trial, there is sentencing
Tar éis na trialach, tagann an bhreith
At any stage in criminal proceedings against you in court, you may decide to plead guilty to the offence
Is féidir leat pléadáil ciontach ag aon am le linn an cháis atá curtha i do leith
If you are charged with a summary offence you plead guilty in the District Court
Má tá cion achomaire curtha i do leithpléadáilfidh tú ciontach sa Chúirt Dúiche
The District Court Judge will then issue your sentence after listening to your legal representative and the prosecution (usually a member of An Garda Siochana - the Irish police force)

Tabharfaidh an Breitheamh sa Chúirt Dúiche a bhreith/breith agus gearrfaidh sé/sí breith ort tar éis dó/di éisteacht le do ionadaí dleathach agus lena bhfuil le rá ag na cúisitheoirí (Gárda a bhíonn ann de ghnáth)
If you are charged with an indictable offence and you decide to plead guilty when you appear in the District Court, you will be required to sign pleas of guilt
Má tá cion indíotáilte curtha i do leith agus go bhfuil tú ag pléadáil ciontach sa Chúirt Dúiche, beidh ort "pléadálanna an chiontaigh" a shiniú
Before you sign the pleas of guilt, the District Judge will first make sure that you are aware of the facts alleged against you and that you understand the nature of the offence
Sula síníonn tú an cáipéis seo déanfaidh an breitheamh cinnte de go bhfuil a fhios agat céard í an choir atá curtha i do leith agus go dtuigeann tú na fíricí a bhaineann leis an gcás
You will then be sent forward to the Circuit Court for sentencing
Cuirfear ar aghaidh ansin tú chuig an Chúirt Chuarda áit a dtabharfar breith ort
If you change your mind, you may withdraw your pleas of guilt at the Circuit Court and the trial will go ahead
Má thagann athrú intinne ort is féidir leat do phléadáil ciontach a tharraingt siar agus rachaidh an triail ar aghaidh ansin
If you have pleaded not guilty in the District Court and you have been sent forward for trial by a judge and jury, you may then decide to plead guilty to the offence

Má phléadáil tú "neamh chiontach" sa Chúirt Dúiche agus go bhfuil tú seolta ar aghaidh chun trialach faoi bhreitheamh agus giúiré, is féidir leat ansin pléadáil "ciontach" don choir atá curtha i do leith
If you plead guilty at the Circuit Court, you will stand convicted and the court will then decide your sentence
Má deireann tú go bhfuil tú ciontach sa Chúirt Chuarda, beidh tú ciontaithe agus déanfaidh an chúirt cinneadh faoin mbreith atá le tabhairt ort
If you are charged with a summary offence, a judge sitting without a jury will decide your case
Má tá cion achomaire curtha i do leith, beidh do chás ós comhair breitheamh gan aon ghiúiré i láthair
It will take place in the District Court
Beidh sé ar siúl sa Chúirt Dúiche
A summary trial will usually take the following format
Beidh an leagan amach seo ar thriail achomaire:
• The Registrar of the District Court will call your case by its name
• Glaofaidh Cláraitheoir na Cúirte Dúiche amach do chás de réir ainm
• You or your legal representative will stand up to make yourself known to the court
• Seasfaidh tú féin agus do ionadaí dlí suas chun sibh féin a chur in aithne don chúirt
• The Garda (member of the Irish police force) who has made the complaint against you will take the witness stand and give evidence about the offence - i.e., what happened
• Seasfaidh an Gárda a rinne an gearán i do choinne ag clár na mionn agus tabharfaidh sé fianaise faoin gcoir atá curtha i do leith - sé sin, céard a thárla
• The defence may cross-examine the Garda
• Is féidir leis an abhcóide cosanta an Gárda a cheistniú
• The prosecution may call any more witnesses and will question the witnesses to allow them to give evidence about the offence
• Cuirfidh na cúisitheoirí fios ar fhinné agus ceistneoidh siad iad chun deis a thabhairt dóibh fianaise a thabhairt maidir leis an gcoir
• The defence may cross-examine each of the prosecution witnesses after they have given evidence
• Tá cead ag an abhcóide cosanta finné na gcúisitheoirí a chroscheistniú nuair a bhíonn a bhfianaise tugtha acu
• The defence may call and question witnesses to give evidence in your defence
• Is féidir leis an abhcóide cosanta finné a ghlaoch chun fianaise a thabhairt ar do shon
You yourself may give evidence although you are not obliged to do so
Is féidir leat féin fianaise a thabhairt, freisin, cé nach bhfuil aon iallach ort sin a dhéanamh
• The prosecution may cross-examine each of your witnesses
• Tá cead ag na cúisitheoirí gach duine de do fhinné a chroscheistniú
• Both the prosecution and the defence may make final submissions relating to the case
• Is féidir leis na cúisitheoirí agus le do thaobh cosanta áiteamh deireadh a dhéanamh maidir leis an gcás
• The judge will make their decision about whether you are guilty or not guilty of the offence, based on the evidence given
• Déanfaidh an Breitheamh cinneadh an bhfuil tú ciontach nó neamhchiontach ag brath ar an bhfianaise atá curtha ós a chomhair/a comhair
To find you guilty, they must believe that it has been proven beyond all reasonable doubt that you are guilty
Sula bhfaigheann sé/sí ciontach tú ní mór go gcreidfeadh sé/sí gur cruthaíodh thar aon amhras reasúnta go bhfuil tú ciontach
• If the judge finds that you are guilty of the offence, they may decide the sentence
• Má fhaigheann an Breitheamh ciontach tú sa choir a cuireadh i do leith, is féidir leis/lei réiteach cad é an bhreith atá le dhul ort
If the judge finds that you are not guilty, they will dismiss the charges against you
Má fhaigheann an Breitheamh neamhchiontach tú, caithfidh sé/sí amach an cás a bhí curtha i do leith
Criminal jury trials are held in the Circuit Court and the Central Criminal Court and usually follow the following format:
An Chúirt Chuarda agus an Phríomh-Chúirt Choiriúil a éisteacht trialacha giúiré coiriúla agus leanann siad de ghnáth an fhormáid seo a leanas:
• The indictment is read out, which lists the offences (counts) to which you have pleaded not guilty
• Léifear amach an díotáil, ina léirítear na cionta (scóir) ar phléadáil an cosantóir neamhchiontach dóibh
• The opening speech of the trial is made by the prosecution
• Is é an lucht ionchúisimh a thugann óráid tosaigh na trialach
The prosecution counsel opens the case and tells the jury about matters that the prosecution intends to prove
Cuireann an t-abhcóide tús leis an gcás agus insíonn don ghiúiré faoi nithe ar mian leis na hionchúisitheoirí a chruthú
Counsel gives an outline of the facts and evidence that the prosecution intends to call
Imlíníonn an t-abhcóide na fíricí agus an fhianaise a bhfuil sé ar intinn ag na cúisitheoirí a thaispeáint
They explain the nature of the charges alleged against the accused
Míníonn sé nó sí na cúiseanna atá líomhanta i leith an chosantóra
• After the opening address to the jury, the prosecution calls witnesses, usually in the order listed in the Book of Evidence
• Tar éis an aithisc thosaigh, glaonn na cúisitheoirí ar fhinnéithe, de réir ord an leabhair fhianaise de ghnáth
Counsel asks the witnesses questions to allow them to tell their story and give their evidence in their own words
Fiafraíonn an t-abhcóide ceisteanna díobh le ligean dóibh a scéal agus a bhfianaise a insint ina bhfocail féin
Documents and statements may be introduced
Féadtar cáipéisí agus ráitis a thabhairt i gcás
Forensic evidence may be introduced as exhibits and the jury is usually given an opportunity to examine such exhibits
Féadtar fianaise fhóiréinseach a chur faoi bhráid na cúirte mar fhoilseáin agus de ghnáth tugtar deis don ghiúiré na foilseáin sin a scrúdú
• When the prosecuting counsel has finished asking each witness questions, the defence counsel may cross-examine the witness
• Nuair a bhíonn an t-abhcóide ionchúisimh críochnaithe ag cur ceisteanna ar gach finné, féadann abhcóide an chosantóra an fhinné a "chroscheistiú"
If the defence intends to challenge a prosecution witness's evidence, the defence counsel must explain the basis for the challenge to the witness
Má bhíonn sé ar intinn ag an lucht cosanta dúshlán a thabhairt faoi fhianaise fhinné na gcúisitheoirí, caitheann an t-abhcóide cosanta bunús an dúshláin a mhíniú don fhinné
• When the prosecuting counsel has finished presenting the case for the prosecution, the defence begins
• Nuair a bhíonn deireadh curtha ag an abhcóide ionchúisimh le cur i láthair an cháis ionchúisimh, is ansin a thosóidh an chosaint
The defence counsel opens the defence and calls witnesses and introduces evidence
Osclóidh an t-abhcóide cosanta an chosaint agus glaofaidh sé nó sí ar fhinnéithe agus tabharfaidh fianaise isteach
Each witness may be cross-examined by the prosecution
Is féidir leis an lucht ionchúisimh gach finné a chroscheistiú
As you are the accused you are not obliged to give evidence
Ní gá don chúisí aon fhianaise a thabhairt
• At the end of the case, both the prosecution and the defence counsel summarise the facts for the jury and emphasise the merits of their own case
• Ag deireadh an cháis déanann na cúisitheoirí agus na cosantóirí araon achoimriú ar na fíricí don ghiúiré agus leagann siad béim ar bhuanna a gcás féin
• At the end of the trial, the judge sums up the case for the jury
• Ag deireadh na trialach coimríonn an breitheam an cás don ghiúiré
They explain the jury's function and directs the jury to confine itself to the evidence presented in court and to disregard any media reports

Míníonn sé nó sí feidhm an ghiúiré dóibh agus treoraíonn sé nó sí don ghiúiré a n-aird a dhíriú ar an bhfianaise a cuireadh faoi bhráid na cúirte amháin agus neamhaird a dhéanamh d’aon tuairiscí sna meáin chumarsáide
• The judge must direct the jury on any legal points that arise
• Caithfidh an breitheamh an giúiré a threorú maidir le haon phointe dlí a thagann aníos
For example, they may explain the legal ingredients of the offence of murder so that the jury can arrive at a verdict that conforms to that legal rule
Mar shampla, féadann sé nó sí bunábhair dhlíthiúla chion an dúnmharaithe a mhíniú ionas gur féidir leis an ngiúiré a theacht ar fhíorasc a chloíonn leis an riail dhlíthiúil sin
• As the case is a criminal one, the judge will also explain to the jury that it must be satisfied of your guilt beyond reasonable doubt
• Más cás coiriúil atá ann, caithfidh an breitheamh a mhíniú don ghiúiré gur ghá go mbeidís sásta faoi chiontacht an chúisithe thar aon amhras réasúnta

Beyond reasonable doubt means that if there are two reasons given in the case and both are possible explanations for what happened, taken together with the evidence presented, the jury should give you the benefit of the doubt

Ciallaíonn thar aon amhras réasúnta má thugtar dhá fháth sa chás, agus más míniú féideartha ar ar tharla araon iad, ba chóir don ghiúiré, i dteannta leis an bhfianaise a cuireadh i láthair, sochar an amhrais a thabhairt don chúisí
